title: CREC Steve Zwinger: Organic wheat/flax intercropping

tasks.task: Participating in a tour of an organic research field trial.
subtasks: Standing on organic-certified ground.
Observing and discussing intercropping methods, particularly wheat and flax.
Learning about the history of wheat and flax intercropping research.
Understanding the impact of varying seeding rates on crop yields.
Considering the challenges and benefits of organic farming practices.
Examining the results of current trials, including impacts of environmental factors and previous cover crops.

tasks.task: Conducting research on organic wheat and flax intercropping.
subtasks: Implementing intercropping trials with specified varieties (FBC Dillon, Glen Wheat, Omega Flax, N.D. Hammond).
Adjusting seeding rates for organic production needs.
Monitoring growth conditions and their effects on yield.
Evaluating the competitive ability of crops under organic management.
Comparing conventional and organic yields for various crops.
Adapting techniques based on historical research (e.g., Dr. Pat Carr's studies from 1991).

tasks.task: Managing a research site's organic certification.
subtasks: Ensuring compliance with organic standards in crop trials.
Rotating crops and using cover crops to manage weeds.
Avoiding synthetic herbicides and pesticide use in favor of natural alternatives.
Monitoring soil health and adjusting practices as necessary.
Complying with organic certification requirements for trials.
Dealing with pests, diseases, and weeds without chemical control.
Optimizing water and nutrient management in dry conditions.
Evaluating the impact of cover crops on subsequent crops.
Adjusting planting strategies based on field conditions.
Assessing the effectiveness of sowing methods (e.g., broadcasting) in organic systems.

tasks.task: Analyzing data from trials and historic reports.
subtasks: Comparing past and present yields for wheat and flax under different rates.
Evaluating the economic viability of organic flax intercropping.
Adjusting experimental designs based on previous data (e.g., two-thirds rate trials).
Refining the intercropping approach for better performance and profitability.
Sharing findings with the agricultural community through reports and presentations.
